title: Embattled Cuadrilla says gas from second well 'highest quality yet'
text:
Cuadrilla is hoping to persuade the government to relax the tight regulatory framework around fracking - which has led to frequent temporary stoppages and now a full shutdown - by demonstrating the potential scale and quality of this onshore energy source.

Mr Egan said the gas was almost impurity-free, and its high calorific value (about 89 per cent methane, 6 per cent ethane and 2 per cent propane) meant that "once separated out at surface from any accompanying water, this gas could, we believe, flow directly into the UK's extensive onshore gas transportation network without requiring additional treatment or processing".

Fracking, or hydraulic fracturing, involves pumping sand, water and chemicals into wells at high pressure and high volume, creating cracks and releasing gas.

The process can cause earth tremors, which means fracking has been a sensitive issue in Britain. Cuadrilla last year won a seven-year battle to restart operations, but the government's tight system of regulation means an 18-hour pause is needed every time a tremor is recorded that exceeds 0.5 on the Richter scale.

Cuadrilla has downplayed the significance of the tremors, describing some of those triggered as akin to "dropping a shopping bag on the floor" or "a toddler playing on a wooden floor".

But although the government has accepted that domestic shale gas may be a valuable natural resource as Britain transitions to net zero carbon emissions by 2050, it has shown little appetite or urgency to rewrite the rules.

"The case for using high quality locally sourced natural gas supply over expensive, increasingly distant, potentially insecure and higher CO2 emitting imports remains stronger than ever," Mr Egan said.

Cuadrilla's fracking permit expires in November, although it has the right to stay on site until April 2023.

The company will be sweating on the result of a December election, if it is called on Tuesday (Wednesday AEDT): the opposition Labour Party has promised to ban fracking altogether.
description: Green groups say the project is 'dead', but the fracking company half-owned by ASX-listed AJ Lucas is still fighting.
